sections.title: Resources to Inform Solvent Selection
sections.text:
With the hazards
of several solvents established, it is important to consider what
role solvents play in a reaction, and what resources are available
to inform the decisions made in selecting them. Specifically, the use of a solvent is key to enable mixing and mass transport between phases and can have an influence on both the rate and selectivity
,
 of a particular
process.
,
 Perhaps the most important use
of solvents is from a safety perspective, wherein the reaction medium
typically acts as a “heat sink” to control exotherms
arising from the reaction. Solvents also are widely utilized in techniques
involved in product isolation and though we will not consider this
here, in cleaning protocols. While many
are beyond the scope of this perspective, it is important to note
that several suggested “greener alternatives” have been
investigated that avoid the use of a conventional reaction solvent
including running reactions neat, solid-phase
reactions as well as employing surfactants
to enable chemistry in aqueous media or exploring emerging options for conducting reactions such as ionic
liquids or supercritical fluids. It cannot be overemphasized how important the
selection of a solvent is not only in dissolving and dispersing the reaction
participants but also in being of the appropriate polarity to promote the chemistry (SN2, E1CB, etc.) and through modification of the solute properties
(redox potential, pKa, H-bonding). Add to this the benefits gained through removing impurities/byproducts
through partitioning, and isolation
of the desired product by crystallization demonstrates how selection of the right solvent from the outset
can alleviate issues with downstream processing. The contribution of the solvent toward the Process Mass
Intensity (PMI) of a process only exacerbates this decision and most
notably how the potential hazards arising from this should be minimized. The ACS Green Chemistry Institute Pharmaceutical Roundtable (ACS-GCIPR)
was established in 2005 when the ACS Green Chemistry Institute and
a handful of pharmaceutical companies saw an opportunity to work together
in a precompetitive manner to promote green chemistry and engineering
innovation. One of the major initiatives of the ACS-GCIPR is the development
of a robust suite of tools that embrace
commonly agreed-upon metrics and support chemists’ choices
around material and method selection to maximize resource efficiency,
minimize hazards, and reduce waste and cost over the life cycle of
the process. While initially developed
by and for the pharmaceutical industry, it should be emphasized that
these tools are also useful and accessible to the broader chemistry
and chemical engineering communities. Two such resources have been developed with respect to solvent selection,
namely a solvent guide and a solvent
selection tool. While the former provides
tabulated information ranking solvents through evaluation of various
properties, the latter allows a more prospective approach to solvent
selection/optimization through identification of suitable reaction
media utilizing the desired properties to facilitate the process as
inputs. While the properties of a solvent are key to making
an informed
decision, there are other factors that need to be considered. Obviously,
the chemistry must work, and it is important that the solvent is also
inert under the reaction conditions, while enabling the workup/isolation
of the desired product can also streamline the process. Solvent recovery
and potential for recycling should be considered, while safety and
potential hazards to both health and the environment are critical.
Overall cost not only to purchase the material but also to dispose
of the waste stream in compliance with the relevant legislation must
be kept in mind. The term “green solvent” is widely
employed in the chemistry literature, and it is important to establish
criteria for a material to meet with this definition. Specifically, a material should be derived
from a renewable feedstock and place low demands on the energy required
to produce it. The solvent should also be biodegradable, insoluble
in water, and have a midrange boiling point in that it is not too
low as to be considered a VOC and not too high in that it is difficult
to recycle. Married to these characteristics should be the properties
of materials that are considered to be “safe” solvents
with high stability, low flammability (high FP) and low to moderate
toxicity. Often during discussions regarding the development/utilization
of solvents, the environmental impacts associated with the overall
manufacture of the materials are overlooked though they are a vital
part of the complete picture. While a detailed discussion of this
is beyond the scope of this perspective, it is, however, critical
for the scientist to have knowledge of the factors involved to allow
for both the judicious selection of current reaction solvents to be
made as well as a critical benchmarking of the processes reported
to produce emerging “greener” reaction solvents. In
addition, when considering aspects of worker safety, it is important
also to consider workers associated with the various manufacturing
processes in addition to the end user. In many cases, the manufacturing
processes for a solvent are energy-intensive and generate significant
greenhouse gas emissions, thus contributing to climate change, with
this issue being exacerbated by the requisite transportation of solvents
to various locations for use. As noted, many solvents are volatile
organic compounds (VOCs) that vaporize quickly at room temperature
and, during manufacture, can escape into the atmosphere. Reactions
occur with other chemicals contributing to ground-level ozone, which
is a component of smog. Not only does this contribute to air pollution
but also leads to impacts on health, such as causing respiratory issues
and triggering asthma. Many manufacturing processes for solvents also
generate wastewater that can often contain chemical pollutants, with
stringent control measures required to prevent these entering waterways
to contaminate aquatic ecosystems. With newer reaction media, much
onus is placed on these being derived from renewable feedstocks as
most of the current solvents we utilize are derived from oil and gas,
which are finite resources, though the overall proposed manufacture
of a new solvent (or a conventional solvent from renewable feedstocks)
has to be considered as more hazardous processes may be involved if
a biobased feedstock is employed as the raw material. In addition, for a complete lifecycle analysis
of a solvent to be derived, the extraction/processing of the raw materials
also needs to be considered. While developing
newer reaction media represents an aspirational long-term goal, one
key factor which should be implemented where viable to mitigate the
environmental impact of a solvent is solvent recovery/recycling systems
that reduce waste and can save costs/resources through enabling reuse
of a solvent. However, in discovery,
implementing such systems is often not viable owing to the scales
involved, while in pharmaceutical industry development/manufacturing,
there are regulatory guidelines to comply with.

sections.title: Solvent Guides/Tables
sections.text:
As noted, there are numerous
solvent guides readily available, though they all represent variations
on a theme most notably in how the relevant information is presented.
Behind each of these guides, though, three common themes emerge: worker
safety, process safety, and environmental and regulatory considerations.
These are then broken down into various subcategories, which can be
“scored” for each of the solvents under consideration
based on the available data, with the range of scores across categories
then weighted according to the specific guide to provide an overall
desirability for each specific solvent (and class). Typically, the
guides are presented in a manner that allows granular decisions to
be made based not only on the overall rankings of solvents but also
on differentiation in the three areas defined above. Within these,
for worker safety, carcinogenicity,
mutagenicity, reprotoxicity, skin absorption/sensitization, and toxicity
are typically considered, while for process safety, flammability,
potential for high emissions (high vapor pressure), peroxide formation, static charge, and odor issues are considered.
Finally, ecotoxicity, potential groundwater contamination, EHS regulatory restrictions, ozone depletion, photoreactivity, and compliance with all relevant
legislation are all part of an evaluation of environmental and regulatory
considerations. A survey of the
solvent selection guides published shows there to be approximately
67% agreement in terms of the classifications of the materials evaluated.
While there is excellent agreement in terms of most solvents that
are either recommended or highly hazardous, there are discrepancies
distinguishing between recommended/problematic or problematic/hazardous
classifications based on a different weighting of the criteria used
in the assembly of discrete guides. The IMI-Chem21 project funded
through the EFPIA (European Foundation of Pharmaceutical Industries
and Associations) and the European Union comprised of a number of
companies (including several pharmaceutical companies) and universities
with the overall remit to develop sustainable biological and chemical
methodologies both through supporting research as well as providing
training packages. One of the components
of the latter was the development of a common solvent selection guide
to allow a preliminary assessment of a solvent’s desirability
to be used for scale-up purposes in the fine chemical industry. This
guide not only includes classical solvents, but also is extended to
newer solvents as well as highlighting bioderived solvents. Although the guide was assembled as part of
a collaborative effort, like in all such endeavors, there are potential
gaps in the methodology used with suggestions that the health criteria
should be based on OEL (Occupational Exposure Limit) while the environmental scoring should include the CO2 synthesis impact/GWP (Global Warming Potential). However, it is stressed that the tool is intended
for a preliminary assessment, with further discussion encouraged in
specific cases to challenge the ranking. For the Chem21 solvent
guide, the scoring (score in each category
between 1 and 10) and ranking are determined as follows. The physical
data and GHS (globalized harmonized system) hazard statements are collected from the SDS, and the safety
score is calculated using the flash point, autoignition temperature,
resistivity, ability to form peroxides, etc. This proves the easiest
to establish as while the health score reflecting the occupational
hazard would most ideally be linked to the OELs, these are only established
for the most common solvents, and in addition, these threshold limits
are not unified. The health score is therefore linked to the most
stringent H3xx statement, thus capturing the potential severity of
the hazard as well as the range of impact. To these scores, a modifier
of “plus 1” is added if the boiling point is less than
86 °C. For solvents with incomplete toxicological data, a default
score of 5 is assigned. The environmental scoring is still not complete
based on lack of data for some materials though it is based on boiling
point as well as the nature of the H4xx statement. For each solvent,
three scores (HS&E) are determined with the ranking determined
by a combination of these. Solvents with one score >8 or two scores
>7 are classified as “hazardous” (red), one score
=
7 or two scores between 4 and 6 are assigned “problematic”
(yellow), while all other solvents are “recommended”
(green). The version of the guide showing 53 common solvents
is shown in Figure 
. As the ranking
system does not distinguish between “hazardous” and
“highly hazardous” solvents, several have been defined
as the latter based on group discussion. With the methodology, 36
solvents present a clear ranking with an 81% concordance with that
obtained from the survey of the other published solvent selection
guides, though it should be noted that in some cases this tool underestimates
both the health and safety hazards presented by a specific solvent.
In the cases in which a clear ranking was not determined, the default
appears to be close to that previously reported. Chem21 solvent selection
guide. Reproduced from ref.  with permission from the
Royal Society of Chemistry. This methodology was also applied to a series of
emerging solvents
that have been purported as “greener” replacements for
classical solvents. The data are presented in Figure 
, and while highlighting the value of some
of these alternative reaction media, it also serves to focus on areas
in which more information is needed regarding both their ecotoxicity
and general toxicity profiles. For some as well, it is also key to
ensuring reaction compatibility prior to utilization. Chem21 solvent selection
guide: Emerging “greener”
solvents. Reproduced from ref.  with permission from the Royal Society of Chemistry.

sections.title: ACS-GCIPR Solvent Selection Tool
sections.text:
“What would
serve as a suitable replacement solvent” is a typical question
that arises during the optimization of a chemical reaction, and usually,
the obvious answer to this is to consider homologues of what the currently
employed solvent is. For example, we replaced methanol with ethanol.
However, this analysis can be somewhat flawed as it offers the question
as to not only whether ethanol is the best alternative but also whether
methanol was actually the best starting point. An alternative way
to consider this is to find a way to define whether solvents are “similar”
or “different” in behavior beyond simple chemical functionality
and to search for the ideal solvent based on the needs of the reaction.
While the solvent selection guides, we have considered aid in identifying
solvents, they are typically utilized for postselection comparison
between the solvent options. While this is valuable, it should be
considered that often making an objective decision can be compromised
by several factors, notably, what solvents are readily in hand, what
did the chemist use last time for such a transformation, or the commercial
availability of the solvent. With these factors in mind, the choice
of solvent is restricted to a simple consideration of the chemistry
(polarity, incompatible functionality, and temperature range). The ACS-GCIPR solvent selection tool reverses this philosophy and
focuses on the molecular properties as opposed to the solvents themselves
and looks to see the properties that will either interfere with or
facilitate the proposed process with the ideal selection envisioned
to work across the reaction, workup, and isolation steps. The tool
features 272 solvents including research, process, and next-generation
green solvents with ∼100 options included for the user to filter/highlight
to help identify the best for their given reaction. Included herein
are a range of 30 physicochemical properties for each solvent including
rudimentary experimental data like boiling/melting points, viscosity,
or other safety markers like flash/ignition points, which can be combined
with properties that capture aspects of the solvent’s polarity,
polarizability, and hydrogen-bonding ability, such as dielectric constants,
dipole moments, or Hansen parameters to name a few. The filter tab
also allows the user to select or discard different functional groups
in order to restrict the output to a given class of solvents. Other
categories that can be evaluated are impacts on health, environmental
effects on air and water, life-cycle assessment, and ICH solvent information
(Figure 
). What the
tool intends to do is to enable the user to define the requirements
of their application with a set of 272 solvents and then be dynamically
interrogated to provide a shortlist of hits meeting these parameters. ACS-GCIPR
solvent selection tool. The objectivity highlighted through the solvent
selection tool
represents the key differentiator in that during this phase of the
workflow leading to the identification of the shortlist, the specific
identities of the solvents are never explicitly revealed. This serves
to not only remove any inherent biases but also facilitate the opportunity
to identify less obvious solvents that may be potentially advantageous
for a specific application. At this juncture, it is instructive
to learn how the tool works
and to validate its performance given the body of knowledge that the
scientific community has accumulated over time regarding classical
solvents. The first challenge is to break down each solvent into a
series of descriptors with many of these being identified, such as
chemical functionality, molecular descriptors, physical properties,
regulatory classification, legal controls, environmental impact, and
health and safety performance with numerous subcategories present
in many of these. In evaluating a solvent for a specific purpose,
some or all of these descriptors could be important in making the
right decision, while it can be challenging making comparisons while
balancing the impact of a wide range of parameters. To achieve this
and enable identifying “similar” and “different”
options, it is necessary to represent solvents at a level beyond the
individual molecular properties. For this purpose, using a multivariate
technique such as Principal Component Analysis (PCA) allows many potentially
correlated parameters to be reduced to a small number of descriptors. For the solvent data, PCA identified 5 principal
components, enabling a model to be generated to distribute the solvents
in 5-dimensional space (PC1 through PC5). There have been various
reports on utilizing PCA for the analysis of solvents though a facile
method to understand this is that when considering how a solvent may
interact with a solute, there are several potential mechanisms that
may be at play, which may all depend to varying degrees of different
properties of the solvent molecule under consideration. Given this, PCA is an established method to
“combine” and “weight” a series of experimental/computed
properties of a solvent into discrete parameters (PC1, PC2, etc.)
to enable benchmarking/comparison studies of solvents to be carried
out effectively using the selection tool. The default view in
the tool is the projection in the plane of
the most dominant descriptors (PC1, PC2), and initial validation of
the tool can be derived when one visualizes solvents with the same
primary functionality (homologues within the same series) across these
two vectors with the outcome that they occur in very close proximity
to each other on the plot. From a high-level perspective, PC1 is the
dominant descriptor representing a global lipophilicity (hydrophobicity)-polarity
scale, while PC2 captures the next most significant characteristics
and provides a representation of the hydrogen-bonding ability of a
solvent. Subsequent PCs (PC3–PC5) account for progressively
smaller amounts of the total variance, signifying finer distinctions
in a solvent’s properties (volume, 3D shape, surface area,
etc.). Within the analysis, it is important to bear in mind that a
specific property/molecular descriptor can be embedded into multiple
PCs though with a variation in terms of its weighting/contribution
to that global property. In addition to validation of the generated
PCA map through observed clustering of a related chemical series of
esters, correlation with observed chemical phenomena (keto-enol tautomerism, O- vs C-alkylation, rates of SNAr reactions, etc.) provides further authentication of the value
of this approach. While it is intuitive to infer that those solvents
in proximity on the map are similar, this may not be the case in all
dimensions, demonstrating that solvents that at first inspection appear
very different (for example, in terms of functionality) may offer
more similarities than simple chemical functionality may suggest,
thus highlighting the value of this approach (Figure 
). While the background to how the data are
compiled and validated is useful to know, many users can exploit the
tool simply to provide a graphical view of the solvent shortlist. ACS-GCIPR
solvent selection tool: Comparing solvents through PCA
analysis. Figure 
 illustrates
two high-level scenarios in which the value of utilization of the
solvent selection tool might be realized. The first is a screening
scenario in which a new reaction is being considered, and it is not
clear what is required in terms of solvent properties for the application
(Figure 
a). The remit
being screening already implies that there is only limited information
available to start a search, and as such the exercise is truly holistic.
Herein identifying an initial hit is useful, and then applying appropriate
filters will provide a shortlist of possible alternatives to evaluate.
Given the nature of the exercise, avoiding aggressive application
of the filters is beneficial. Furthermore, when the desired view has
been generated, a selection of representative solvent candidates from
discrete quadrants will provide a first-pass evaluation as to the
desirable property space for the solvent for the transformation under
investigation. Utilization of the ACS-GCIPR solvent selection tool: (a)
Screening
for new potential reaction solvents; (b) Solvent optimization/replacement. A second scenario is perhaps more clear-cut being
an optimization
in which an initial hit is known (perhaps identified through screening),
though replacement options are desired (Figure 
b). In this case, it is reasonable to expect
that proximal solvents to the initial hit on the PCA map will provide
some degree of “similar” behavior. With this, applying
filters to a localized subset should provide a reasonable starting
point, while expanding/reducing the scope of these criteria is possible
depending on the scope/goals of the optimization study. In this scenario,
the tool serves as an “idea generator” and evaluating
across the various components while filtering using the properties
options allows a user to generate a “shortlist” that
can then be experimentally evaluated through a further screening campaign.
The ease of use and speed of the tool allow this to be achieved in
a relatively expeditious manner.

sections.title: Analysis of Solvent Usage in Common Reactions
sections.text:
Often,
the selection of a solvent for a specific transformation is based
on legacy experience, and given this and the established nature of
organic synthesis, we hypothesized that certain synthetic transformations
are more likely to rely on hazardous or problematic solvents than
others. Given this, we sought to gain a more thorough understanding
on which reaction classes have placed a strong reliance on what we
would consider to be poor solvent selections. To achieve this, we
revisited the solvent usage habits across the Medicinal Chemistry
community by surveying what reaction media were used for the most
recurrent synthetic transformation classes as previously identified
from the experimentals of J. Med. Chem. by Brown
and Bostrom in 2016.
,
 In addition to these fundamental
reactions, the central role that heterocyclic systems play in medicinal
chemistry is also taken into account with the analysis extended to
evaluate “heterocyclic synthesis”, which provides data
on the solvents utilized for reactions employed in the formation of
3, 4, 5, and 6-membered heteroatom-containing rings (N, O, and S). We conducted our SciFinder-n survey on these
transformations across a broader time frame (2000–2021) though
once again limiting the scope of our investigation to articles from J. Med. Chem. Each synthetic transformation was defined
by a structural search with remarkably ∼70% of the total reactions
undertaken coming from just six of the 20 classes (excluding “heterocycle
synthesis” from this analysis as this covers a broader range
of reaction types) that were evaluated (Figure 
). Common transformations in medicinal chemistry
(J. Med.
Chem. 2000–2021). A visual depiction of the solvent usage data is
displayed in Figure 
 in which the number
of incidences of the use of undesirable solvents is expressed as a
percentage of the total number of occurrences for each specific reaction
class. It can be noted in the analyses presented that in addition
to granular metrics regarding the use of the unsustainable solvents
highlighted in this review, data on a subset of other “hazardous”
solvents are presented. Although this category features a range of
solvents that are employed on a more sporadic basis, it demonstrates
that benzene, pyridine, carbon tetrachloride (and other chlorinated solvents), di-iso-propyl ether
,
 and HMPA have all been used as reaction media within
medicinal chemistry programs, and as with the featured unsustainable
solvents, replacing these materials in reactions of interest is strongly
recommended. Percentage uses of the solvents/reaction class. Overall, evaluating the data, it can clearly be
seen that across
all reaction classes the use of the problematic solvents DMF and DCM
is prevalent, though despite this and the lesser use of solvents such
as Et2O, DME, dioxane, DCE, and NMP, the latter group still
sees significant use and throughout these applications, the potential
replacement with greener alternatives would be beneficial. In addition,
the data demonstrate that often a specific solvent is selected for
a discrete reaction class, thus reinforcing the hypothesis that solvent
selection is often based on legacy experience. Examples of this observation
include 1,4-dioxane for Suzuki–Miyaura (∼26%), Buchwald–Hartwig couplings (∼28%), and Boc protection/deprotections (∼11/13%); DME for Suzuki–Miyaura couplings (∼14%) and notably diethyl ether for the addition
of organometallic reagents to electrophiles (∼17%) (e.g., Grignard
reactions). Notably for these applications
involving ethereal solvents, medicinal chemists are encouraged to
test more environmentally benign derivatives like 2-MeTHF and CPME (vide infra), which have been reported to perform in a comparative
manner to those historically used for these applications. Further analysis of these data showed
that among the 20 reaction
classes, two (amide formation and oxidation of alcohols) used unsustainable
solvents in ∼70% of the reported instances, while a further
group of 9 transformations was performed in hazardous reaction solvents
with between 50% and 70% probability (Figure 
). In contrast, only 7 of the reaction classes
were performed in undesirable solvents less than 40% of the number
of times that they were reported. Almost half of the ∼35k amine
alkylations were reported in undesirable solvents with 33% using DMF.
Similarly, ester formation (∼15k hits) was also carried out
∼50% of the time using undesirable solvents (DCM 31%, DMF 13%),
which is somewhat surprising given that these could be avoided if
environmentally benign reaction media such as alcoholic systems are
used with an acid catalyst. The exponential growth of Pd-mediated
couplings over the past 20 years is highlighted by ∼29k examples
of Suzuki–Miyaura couplings being reported in the journal with
over half of these using hazardous solvents most notably those that
are potential carcinogens (1,4-dioxane 26%; DME 14%).
, Overall utilization of nonsustainable/hazardous solvents. While these data are interesting, it is perhaps
more instructive
to focus on what solvent choices are made for the most popular reactions
currently carried out within medicinal chemistry programs. The most
popular is amide bond formation, which is reported on >63k occasions
utilizing DCM or DMF in 28% or 36% respectively of those instances.
,
 In contrast, the formation of heterocycles represents the second
most prevalent transformation (∼56k) using hazardous solvents
∼32% of the time with either DCM or DMF being employed equally
in almost two-thirds of these occurrences. Strategies commonly invoked
for SAR investigations involve employing reactions to efficiently
forge carbon-heteroatom bonds around the periphery of a core bioactive
scaffold. Several transformations allow for the robust formation of
C–N bonds with broad substrate scope enabling their application
in parallel library format to access collections of related molecules
to expedite SAR studies. Specifically, from our data, C­(sp2)–N/O bond formation (most notably Buchwald-Hartwig couplings),
nitrogen alkylation, and reductive amination are exemplified on ∼64k occasions with
47% of these being carried out in solvents, which are “undesirable”.
For each of these transformations, one can easily identify research
opportunities to develop replacements for dioxane (28%, C­(sp2-N/O bond formation), DMF (33%, nitrogen alkylation) and chlorinated
media (29%, reductive amination) for these reactions. There are ∼39k reports of Boc deprotections,
and the data from these highlight one of the challenges often faced
within a Discovery Chemistry environment. Herein for convenience,
a commercial solution of HCl in 1,4-dioxane (4 M) is extensively utilized
as the reagent, thus leading to ∼13% of the reactions being
carried out using this solvent (this is like the statement above regarding
the use of diethyl ether for Grignard reactions given that many of
these reagents are supplied commercially as solutions in this solvent). DCM is also extensively used for Boc deprotections
(∼33% of the time, typically with TFA) while DMF is also often encountered (∼12%) in this
transformation. It is worth noting that all three of these solvents
(DCM, dioxane, and DMF) are also regularly used in reactions to install
the Boc-protecting group. One further observation from the data is
that there is a significant disparity in the reaction data between
the number of instances in which a Boc-protecting group is installed
as opposed to its removal, with the latter dominating by almost 10-fold.
At first glance, this would appear to be counterintuitive as one would
expect these reactions to be somewhat equivalent. However, discovery
chemistry programs rely to a large degree on the commercial availability
of orthogonally protected building blocks and monomers to elaborate
compounds to investigate chemical space. Given this within our programs,
the Boc-protected amine is often employed as a starting material,
and thus, only the removal is carried out within our laboratories. From our survey, the six transformations described thus far account
for almost 70% of the reactions described with the remaining 14 reaction
classes accounting for the remainder. However, distinct trends emerge in the analysis of this subset of
data. Notably, the reduction of aromatic nitro groups to anilines
appears to exhibit the most benign solvent profile with this typically
carried out in solvents such as methanol, ethanol, EtOAc, and THF
in contrast to examples in more problematic reaction media (13%). Perhaps this is not surprising given that this
transformation is often carried out via hydrogenation with a heterogeneous
catalyst and the typical solvents used
present favorable properties in terms of both solubilizing the gas
and facilitating the mass transfer between the three phases. While selecting a potential solvent for this
reaction, one can prioritize using either an alcohol or EtOAc for
this transformation, specifically when the significant energy considerations
associated with the manufacture of THF are considered. This though
is very much the exception with, for example, DMF being frequently
used across phenol alkylation (35%), ester formation (13%), O-debenzylation
(6%) and C­(sp2)–N/C­(sp2)–O bond
formations (7%). As noted, the latter also frequently uses dioxane
(28%), while another ethereal solvent DME is employed in ∼14%
of Suzuki–Miyaura couplings. The analysis of this subset of
reaction classes also highlights DCM as a “go-to” solvent
for numerous transformations including alcohol oxidations (54%, often
in tandem with the Dess–Martin periodinane of related hypervalent-iodine-based
reagents), sulfonamide synthesis (40%),
ester formation (31%) O- (20%), and N-debenzylations (15%). A rationale
presented for the prevalent use of solvents such as DMF and DCM in
medicinal chemistry is often their ability to solubilize a broad range
of organic molecules, though AI/ML-based
predictive methods for compound solubility are emerging, which may
provide an opportunity to select more sustainable reaction media based
specifically on the substrate of interest. With these data in hand, one can immediately reach the conclusion
that significant impacts in terms of sustainability can be gained
within a medicinal chemistry program simply by developing “greener”
conditions specifically with the use of more environmentally benign
solvents for the transformation. To achieve this, the data were further
refined to highlight not only the most recurrent reaction classes
but also those that typically employ undesirable solvents. This led
us to identify the following 12 transformations, which would benefit
from greener reaction conditions with the numbers in parentheses representing
an approximate “count” of the occasions that this reaction
has been performed in a hazardous solvent in the period under review.
These are amide formation (45k), Boc deprotection (26k), amine alkylation
(18k), synthesis of heterocycles (18k), Suzuki–Miyaura coupling
(16k), ester hydrolysis (9k), reductive amination (8k), sulfonamide
synthesis (8k), ester hydrolysis (8k), phenol alkylation (7k), C­(sp2)–N/C­(sp2)–O bond formations (4k),
and oxidation of alcohols (4k). However, despite what might appear
to be a somewhat bleak outlook, from our extensive literature review,
for all of these transformations noted here, there exist numerous
examples in which the reactions are conducted under more sustainable
conditions. In the next section, a series of these have been collated
for each transformation in a readily accessible format, thus enabling
these to be investigated as potential “first-pass” conditions
upon encountering a new substrate without the need for extensive literature
research.

sections.title: Toward Greener Conditions for Commonly Used Transformations
sections.text:
There are several approaches that can be adopted to pursue greener
conditions for a specific transformation under investigation. As highlighted,
the choice of solvent plays a major role in assessing the overall
sustainability of the reaction not only through the relative volume
of possible waste generated but also through its potentially undesirable
properties (toxicity, etc.). Considering this, the strategy of straight
substitution of the solvent for a more sustainable medium presents
a logical path forward, and this can be greatly facilitated using
a solvent guide as previously discussed. This has successfully been
implemented and reported on several occasions for example, the replacement
of DCM with 2-MeTHF for amide bond formations, switching DMF for more
recently developed polar aprotic solvents like cyrene or dimethyl isosorbide in SNAr reactions,
and replacing ether with 2-MeTHF for Grignard chemistry. An extension
of this approach is offered through the solvent selection tool, which
enables the user to utilize the most desirable properties that the
reaction medium should possess to mediate the transformation of interest
(polarity, pKa etc.) and then apply these to identify
solvents that may be of value. With a specific transformation
in mind, the ACS-GCIPR Reagents Guide presents an excellent resource
in providing a starting point for conditions to explore for a given
reaction. Currently this tool covers 29 transformations demonstrating
for each the possible reagents to be utilized in a simple Venn diagram
format, in which conditions are assigned based on criteria around
“wide substrate scope”, “applicability to scale”,
and “greenness”. Naturally those results found at the
intersection of the three circles represent a “sweet spot”
in terms of overall applicability and sustainability (Figure 
). However, within medicinal
chemistry programs, the objective is often speed, and as such, conditions
that have been shown previously to have worked for a wide variety
of examples are the most compelling, though these are often found
to not be particularly attractive from a green perspective. Annotated
ACS-GCIPR reagent guide Venn diagram (alcohol oxidation). The strategies so far discussed focus on either
the choice of solvent
or reagent selection for a specific transformation, which overlooks
the fact that these two discrete parameters are often critically interrelated.
On most occasions when a medicinal chemist is confronted with a new
chemical series to work on, they will search a database (either a
commercial offering such as SciFinder or an institutional ELN: Electronic
Lab Notebook) for reactions that have been run on similar substrates
to provide initial conditions to test. With this workflow, it is highly
likely to perpetuate chemically successful, albeit nonenvironmentally
sustainable reaction conditions given that the methods previously
utilized were largely developed in a time when the importance of sustainability
was not as widely recognized. Based on our extensive data mining
described for obtaining the
solvent usage information, herein we propose an alternative strategy
for the choice of initial reaction conditions to evaluate when faced
with a novel chemical series. Collected in Table 
, one will find a selection of at least three
current, more environmentally sustainable conditions for each of the
ten most common reaction types observed in JMC as previously discussed.
The proposed conditions are ordered from “more conservative”
at the top to “further from precedent” at the bottom,
and we suggest that these can be utilized in situations when a medicinal
chemist is confronted with either a new substrate/chemical series
or perhaps even better when trying to “green” a current
reaction. Each reaction shows a specific substrate with the reaction
conditions and the corresponding references, thus eliminating the
need for the chemist to look up alternate sources, and it is envisioned
that Table 
 will serve
as a valuable resource for “green” conditions for the
above (12) most common reaction types. To assist in both its uptake
and overall utility, a poster version of this information has been
made available in the Supporting Information for use as a Quick Reference Guide. The overall approach suggested
herein is unique in not only in marrying the reagents/solvents for
a specific transformation but also for the fact that in many cases
the selected examples have been performed on pharmaceutically relevant
substrates, thus somewhat mitigating common concerns regarding substrate
solubility under a specific set of reaction conditions, which is often
a major challenge when a simple “solvent swap” is implemented
to “green” a reaction.

sections.title: Analysis of Solvent Usage in Workup/Purification
sections.text:
It
has been widely recognized throughout the industry that the major
contributors to the PMI of a chemical reaction are solvents and water,
and while this is well established particularly in chemical development,
medicinal chemists often use large volumes of water and organic solvents
particularly in the extractive workup of chemical transformations. In fact, the elimination of such workups and
their replacement with solvent swaps through distillation to telescope reaction steps represents a common strategy to drive down PMI numbers
within chemical development. In order
to assay the impact of solvent usage for workup and purification (vide infra) within the medicinal chemistry research phase,
a similar survey to that described previously was conducted of published J. Med. Chem. procedures between 2000 and 2021. To streamline
the analysis, a representative sampling of four publications was chosen
from each year for a total of 80 publications over the 20-year span
leading to 1874 experiments being reviewed. Of these experiments,
it was shown that 53% utilized an extractive aqueous workup procedure
(Figure 
).
,
 In the remaining cases, an extractive workup is avoided either through
direct precipitation of solutes through addition of an antisolvent
or through a simple evaporation to yield the crude product. In contrast to the range of solvents used for
reactions, the options for extraction are more limited based on the
requirement for them to be essentially immiscible with water, and
those utilized in the reactions surveyed are collected in Figure 
. Pleasingly from
a sustainability perspective, over half of the analyzed reactions
used EtOAc (54%) as the solvent for extraction. However, 31% of the reactions utilized hazardous chlorinated
solvents, while 7% used extremely flammable diethyl ether, which is
also prone to peroxide formation. The survey also clearly reveals
that there has been little to no uptake in medicinal chemistry settings
of newly emerging solvents such as MTBE, CPME, and 2-MeTHF for extractions. While these solvents can serve as greener and
safer alternatives to diethyl ether (the flashpoint of diethyl ether
is −40 °C, while that of 2-MeTHF is −12 °C),
2-MeTHF also presents an alternative to dichloromethane, which as
noted has both health and environmental concerns. From a practical
perspective, 2-MeTHF (unlike THF) is immiscible with water and can
thus be used to extract products directly from reaction mixtures without
the formation of emulsions, which is often a challenge with dichloromethane.
One of the drivers often presented for the use of chlorinated solvents
for extraction within medicinal chemistry is that the desired products
are often highly polar and water-soluble, and as such diethyl ether
and EtOAc are ineffective as extraction solvents. Recent work by Reetz and coworkers has identified n-butanol as an ecologically
viable choice for such systems with this solvent proving to be particularly
effective for the extraction of polar compounds from enzymatic processes. Furthermore, simply through reducing both the
number of extractions employed during an aqueous workup and the volume
of solvents utilized during the process can greatly reduce the overall
PMI value of the transformation leading to a more sustainable outcome. Analysis of (a) methods of purification and
(b) extractive workups

The Role of Miniaturization and High-Throughput Experimentation
(HTE) in Greener Solvent Selection and Reducing Solvent Usage

Within medicinal chemistry, access to milligram quantities of bioactive
compounds often suffices for initial profiling in relation to target
biology and metabolic stability, and as such the scale on which one
operates becomes a critical consideration in minimizing waste. A successful discovery campaign will iteratively

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.text:
The Medicinal Chemistry Focus team of ACS-GCIPR
has conducted a
systematic survey of the most common synthetic transformations that
have been carried out within the drug discovery phase over the past
two decades. While these reactions are often performed on a relatively
small scale (milligrams to grams), the amount of solvent utilized
and waste generated is significant given that over 400k reactions
are profiled here. The data clearly indicate that the use of unsustainable/hazardous
solvents is prevalent within the medicinal chemistry community with
over 40% of the reactions being performed in undesirable chlorinated,
dipolar aprotic, ethereal, or hydrocarbon-based solvents with two
transformations (including amide-bond formation, which is the most
prevalent) using unsustainable solvents in over 70% of the instances
surveyed. The survey also examined the common methods and media utilized
for purification and workup of these transformations and again highlights
that most notably methylene chloride is still extensively used in
both chromatography and extractive separations. This manuscript
provides guidance on resources for the proactive
selection of suitable reaction solvents as well as details regarding
solvent guides, which highlight suitable replacement of reaction media
as well as information around emerging “greener” solvents.
In addition, alternative protocols for the ten most encountered synthetic
transformations currently in medicinal chemistry laboratories are
also reported. Finally, the utility of both High-Throughput Experimentation
(HTE) and the emergence of AI/ML techniques for making more judicious
selections of reaction conditions are also reported. The use of solvents
as a whole within Synthetic Organic Chemistry represents a major dichotomy
with regard to Green Chemistry, and while it is acknowledged that
it is highly challenging given their critical roles to eliminate a
solvent (though “safe” minimization is highly encouraged),
making better choices in terms of selecting a reaction medium will
have a major impact on the overall sustainability of not only a specific
reaction but also the drug discovery process in our industry as a
whole. However, it is important to put the overall guidance from this
article in perspective in that herein we consider only the usage phase
of a solvent’s life cycle. While obviously this is a focal
point for the practicing medicinal chemist, from a big-picture sustainability
perspective for the global chemical enterprise, it is an absolute
priority that the full life cycle of a solvent, including its manufacture,
should be taken into account when one seeks to describe it as a “green”
solvent.

sections.title: Significance
sections.text:
Significance: We analyze
reactions reported from Medicinal
Chemistry laboratories over the past 20 years and report on the trends
surrounding the nature of the organic solvents used to perform these
transformations. Impact: The data clearly demonstrate
that ∼50% of the reactions analyzed are run in hazardous, unsustainable
solvents. Innovation: A broad range of strategies is
described, including solvent selection guides/tools, alternative reaction
conditions, and experimental approaches to enable more judicious solvent
selections to be made.

## Introduction
With society placing a greater focus on
the long-term well-being
of the environment and an increased onus on corporate social responsibility
to achieve this, over the last two decades the pharmaceutical industry
has expended a significant effort on improving the sustainability
of their chemical processes. Pivotal to
this initiative has been the formation of the American Chemical Society
Green Chemistry Institute Pharmaceutical Roundtable (ACS-GCIPR), and metrics from members of this group have led
to an estimate that solvents utilized in such processes contribute
to 80–90% in terms of the mass of waste streams and 75–80%
of the overall life cycle impact of pharmaceutical manufacturing processes. Despite this study being carried out 15 years
ago, marginal improvements in decreasing solvent use for small molecule
API (active pharmaceutical ingredient) have been offset not only by
the increasing complexity of the molecules being synthesized but also
by the growth of new therapeutic modalities such as peptides and oligonucleotides, which when performed using classical solid-phase methodologies are
highly solvent-intensive particularly through the multiple resin-washing
cycles involved. While the value of employing a solvent and the roles
that this plays in mediating the transformations of organic compounds
into more complex molecules is well recognized, the extensive use
of such materials has prompted scientists to study and seek to benchmark
the health, safety and environmental (HSE) scores for a diverse array
of solvents leading to the development of various guides to enable
judicious decisions to be made in terms of selection. Typically, these guides either prepared by individual companies
or consortia such as the ACS-GCIPR are in good agreement as to which
solvents present greater hazards to the user as well as the deleterious
effects that they pose to the environment. However, while the value
of the metrics presented on the volumes of solvent utilized in the
industry is unquestionable, these have centered exclusively on amounts
employed in late development or manufacturing campaigns to produce
Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs), and to the best of our knowledge, there are no systematic accounts
that accurately document solvent use in the early exploratory stages
of the drug discovery process when chemical synthesis plays an extensive
role in the production of milligram amounts of potentially thousands
of compounds for evaluation against a specific therapeutic target.
One rationale presented for this is that herein access to the required
compound is the primary goal, and while intensive synthetic efforts
are dedicated to deliver the variety of analogs required for SAR (structure
activity relationship) studies, these often entail the use of suboptimal,
low-yielding fit-for-purpose synthesis routes on milligram scale.
Application of conventional metrics such as Process Mass Intensity
(PMI) to these endeavors is both inconsistent and of questionable
overall value with high values usually being obtained as result of
the low yields and chromatographic purification methods that are typically
utilized. Taken out of context though,
PMI metrics (or similar quantitative measures) on chemistry at the
early stage of drug development strongly imply that sustainability
considerations do not play a role in the selection of the seemingly
nonefficient synthetic routes applied, and that the opportunity to
develop more green approaches to lead compounds only becomes a tangible
consideration as a molecule progresses toward further development
as a potential clinical candidate. In
discovery chemistry, the scale of operations is often cited to mitigate
these metrics though the waste streams generated and subsequent environmental
impact may not be as negligible compared to multikilogram development
and manufacturing campaigns as one envisions particularly given the
sheer number of ongoing medicinal chemistry projects and therefore
compounds being synthesized globally at any one time. In fact, while it is commonly believed that multistep synthesis
on milligram scales minimally impacts sustainability, it has been
estimated that up to 3.5 million kilograms of waste are generated
from drug discovery through preclinical studies. Furthermore, placing the sole reliance for the investigation/implementation
of more sustainable approaches to candidate compounds on the Chemical
Development department creates significant resource pressures for
groups whose primary objectives are based on time-sensitive deliveries
of high-quality materials intended for critical clinical studies. Despite the known hazards of many substances
that are utilized
commonly as solvents within Medicinal chemistry laboratories, the
extensive role(s) and as such the inherent need for a solvent in a
chemical reaction are well recognized. While solvent minimization is a viable strategy in attaining more
favorable Green Chemistry outcomes (prevention of waste), the choice
of solvent is also critical with the use of benign solvents (principle
5) and the desire to do less hazardous chemistry (numbers 3 and 12)
highlighted in the 12 Principles of Green Chemistry. In addition, considerations, such as choosing materials
derived from renewable feedstocks and considering how easy they are
to remove, are important factors. There are several solvent selection
tools to aid in this endeavor, as discussed below. One factor that
is important to bear in mind when making solvent selection for a specific
reaction is the concept of solvent class, as often a more judicious
choice of the medium in which to carry out the reaction can be made
through switching to a related member of the family without losing
any of the benefits. An important concept with this strategy is that,
whereas naturally all chemicals/substances have some drawbacks from
an environmental/sustainability perspective, seeking to minimize these
is at the core of the decision made. The ACS-GCIPR Medicinal Chemistry subteam was created in 2012 with
one of its key initiatives being to both raise awareness and educate
practitioners of the importance and positive downstream impact in
developing more sustainable synthetic routes in early discovery campaigns. Integral and perhaps most challenging to this
objective are to establish a mindset for a researcher to consider
and implement green chemistry right from the outset and to unequivocally
demonstrate that many legacy notions that to achieve this in a fast-paced
drug discovery environment are incorrect. With these objectives in mind, herein we focus on the potential
impact of solvent usage in medicinal chemistry programs through an
in-depth analysis of experimental data from the Journal of Medicinal
Chemistry given that this will serve as a representative reflection
of the synthetic routes employed in an early drug discovery setting. To further cement the validity of this data
set, a period of 20 years (2000–2020) was selected to provide
an accurate illustration of the trends involved, most notably capturing
the promotion of new greener solvent alternatives as well as emerging
chemical methodologies and associated solvent requirements disclosed
during an extended time phase. Not only are the solvents utilized
in specific recurrent chemical transformations considered here but
also those that are employed in both workups and purifications. Furthermore,
we discuss the drivers and incentives for making judicious solvent
selections at an early stage, most notably that such decisions can
accelerate a program through development by avoiding further route
changes/optimizations necessitated through a requirement to switch
the reaction media. It is important to note that the study reported
here evaluates HSE score criteria based on NFPA (National Fire Protection
Association) ratings using the ACS-GCIPR and CHEM21 solvent selection
guides, though other such reports provide similar guidance about the
selection of solvent replacements. This perspective also suggests
a series of preferred conditions from a sustainability perspective
for the top ten most common transformations reported in the medicinal
chemistry literature, while strategies based on miniaturization explicitly
using High Throughput Experimentation (HTE) are discussed as a mechanism
to both reduce solvent volumes and accelerate the identification of
more suitable solvents/conditions for a specific transformation. There are numerous sources of information
available that provide researchers with details regarding the safety
and hazards inherent to a specific solvent/substance that is being
used. Perhaps most valuable is the MSDS
(Material Safety Data Sheet, sometimes referred to as an SDS that
contains the same information) that is supplied with all materials
and can be easily accessed from a vendor’s Web site. The MSDS is defined as a document that provides
workers with procedures for safely handling or working with a particular
substance (Figure 
). Many companies will also retain an internal repository/database
of these as part of their Health and Safety groups. While variations
occur in the appearance of the MSDS based on the source, these documents
are typically templated and consist of 16 sections with sections 1
and 2 dealing with the identification of the substance (and the supplier)
and a high-level description of the hazards, respectively. Section
3 describes the specification of the ingredients, while measures addressing
First Aid, Firefighting, and Accidental Release are the topics for
sections 4 through 6. Section 7 talks of the handling and storage
of the material, while section 8 focuses on the exposure controls
and necessary personal protection for working with the substance in
question. Sections 9 and 10 report the physical/chemical properties
and the stability/reactivity characteristics of the material in question,
while sections 11 and 12 provide information on toxicological and
ecological studies. Sections 13 and 14 provide guidance for the disposal
and transportation of the chemical substance, with section 15 addressing
information regarding regulatory listings. Section 16 is provided
to disclose any relevant information that has not been captured elsewhere
in the document. Representative MSDS with the section descriptors. Table 
 summarizes
some of the properties of these solvents that we will provide an overview
of in this section. Based on space constraints, this is obviously
not a complete list nor is the following discussion an exhaustive
overview as detailed reports of numerous reports on physical properties,
reactivity, and ecological and toxicological profiles of each solvent
exist in the primary literature. The table includes thermal characteristics such as
boiling point,
flash point, and autoignition temperature. The latter two are often
confused, the flash point of a volatile material is the lowest temperature
at which its vapors will ignite if given an ignition source, while
the autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature at which a
substance will spontaneously ignite in a normal atmosphere without
a source of ignition. The NFPA rating system (NFPA 704) provides a
simple visual representation mainly intended for emergency personnel
dealing with a fire or spill to indicate the health (blue), flammability
(red), reactivity (yellow) and special (white) hazards associated
with a specific material. Different colored
sectors are employed to represent the distinct hazards with a number
rating system of 0–4 (0 representing the least and 4 representing
the greatest risk) utilized to rate each of these on the diamond displayed
on the container of the substance. Figure 
 provides an overview of the criteria applied
to assign ratings to materials for each hazard. NFPA rating system. Other labeling systems (HMIS, OSHA HazCom) are
also often used
though they are not discussed here. The
explosive limits for a solvent specify the concentration range of
a material in air which will burn or explode in the presence of an
ignition source and are usually expressed as the percent volume of
the material in the air. The Lower Explosive
Limit (LEL) is the lowest concentration of vapor that will burn in
air and for most flammable gases, it is less than 5% by volume, while
the Upper (or higher) Explosive Limit (UEL) is the highest concentration
of a vapor above which a flame will not spread in the presence of
an ignition source. It is important to note that percentages higher
than the UEL are considered to be “too rich to burn”. The LC50 and LD50 data tabulated provide
a relative assessment to the toxicity of a specific solvent and should
be considered in context. Specifically,
toxicity is divided into multiple categories based on the duration
of exposure. Acute toxicity is typically
associated with a single exposure over a relatively short time, while
chronic toxicity addresses repeated or long-term exposure that occurs
over months to years. LD50 is used to describe acute toxicity and is the median lethal oral
(or dermal) dose predicted to cause death in 50% of the test animals. The values are expressed in milligrams of compound
per kilogram of body weight of the test species (mg/kg). While LD50 is the lethal dose, LC50 refers to the lethal
concentration and is utilized for inhalation-based studies (the values
for the latter can be reported in mg/L, mg/m3, or ppm). Comparisons are often challenging, as it is
important to remember that estimates of the LD50 are specific
to the test animals used in the study and variability is observed
not only between species but also between different studies. As a guideline, compounds with an oral LD50 of 0–50 mg/kg are considered highly toxic, while
an LD50 of >2000 mg/kg is associated with a material
of
low toxicity. Various assessments such as the Hodge/Sterner or Gosselin/Smith/Hodge
scales can be used to compare and provide a more granular description
of LD50 values, and extensive
databases are available typically through subscription such as the
Registry of Toxic Effects of Chemical Substances (RTECS). Even though the hazards presented by several
solvents are well
understood, there are several that still find widespread use and for
some reactions/tasks represent the preferred choice in Medicinal Chemistry
synthesis programs despite their unsustainable nature (Figure 
). These solvents come from specific solvent classes, namely hydrocarbon, chlorinated, ethereal,
and dipolar aprotic solvents with several
recent reviews providing a broad overview of their applications in
synthetic chemistry. A brief overview of each of the solvents is provided
in the following sections with more detailed information around the
hazards of these materials discussed in the Supporting Information. Nonsustainable solvents commonly used in medicinal chemistry. n-Hexane is a very volatile
aliphatic hydrocarbon that is insoluble in water and is commonly used
as a solvent in medicinal chemistry laboratories most notably in chromatographic
separations. Caution must be exercised,
as flammable vapors from this solvent may dissipate away from a spill
and represent an explosion hazard. The odor threshold for hexane is
130 ppm with the solvent reported to have a “faint, peculiar”
odor. Various grades of hexane(s) are
available with the laboratory solvent n-hexane containing
approximately 99% n-hexane, while “hexane”

decomposition with further investigations carried out to establish
the role of concentration/materials, etc., on both the onset temperature

to acute toxicity and its reported propensity to lead to damage the

Substance List owing to citations from a range of regulatory organizations.

broad thus highlighting that caution should be exercised in relying

the chemistry must work, and it is important that the solvent is also
inert under the reaction conditions, while enabling the workup/isolation

and potential for recycling should be considered, while safety and
potential hazards to both health and the environment are critical.

of the waste stream in compliance with the relevant legislation must
be kept in mind. The term “green solvent” is widely
employed in the chemistry literature, and it is important to establish
criteria for a material to meet with this definition. Specifically, a material should be derived
from a renewable feedstock and place low demands on the energy required
to produce it. The solvent should also be biodegradable, insoluble
in water, and have a midrange boiling point in that it is not too
low as to be considered a VOC and not too high in that it is difficult
to recycle. Married to these characteristics should be the properties
of materials that are considered to be “safe” solvents
with high stability, low flammability (high FP) and low to moderate
toxicity. Often during discussions regarding the development/utilization
of solvents, the environmental impacts associated with the overall
manufacture of the materials are overlooked though they are a vital
part of the complete picture. While a detailed discussion of this
is beyond the scope of this perspective, it is, however, critical
for the scientist to have knowledge of the factors involved to allow
for both the judicious selection of current reaction solvents to be
made as well as a critical benchmarking of the processes reported
to produce emerging “greener” reaction solvents. In
addition, when considering aspects of worker safety, it is important
also to consider workers associated with the various manufacturing
processes in addition to the end user. In many cases, the manufacturing

greenhouse gas emissions, thus contributing to climate change, with
this issue being exacerbated by the requisite transportation of solvents

and, during manufacture, can escape into the atmosphere. Reactions
occur with other chemicals contributing to ground-level ozone, which
is a component of smog. Not only does this contribute to air pollution

stringent control measures required to prevent these entering waterways

scientific community has accumulated over time regarding classical
solvents. The first challenge is to break down each solvent into a

chemical functionality, molecular descriptors, physical properties,
regulatory classification, legal controls, environmental impact, and
health and safety performance with numerous subcategories present

reports on utilizing PCA for the analysis of solvents though a facile
method to understand this is that when considering how a solvent may
interact with a solute, there are several potential mechanisms that
may be at play, which may all depend to varying degrees of different
properties of the solvent molecule under consideration. Given this, PCA is an established method to

properties of a solvent into discrete parameters (PC1, PC2, etc.)
to enable benchmarking/comparison studies of solvents to be carried

dominant descriptor representing a global lipophilicity (hydrophobicity)-polarity

and provides a representation of the hydrogen-bonding ability of a
solvent. Subsequent PCs (PC3–PC5) account for progressively
smaller amounts of the total variance, signifying finer distinctions
in a solvent’s properties (volume, 3D shape, surface area,
etc.). Within the analysis, it is important to bear in mind that a
specific property/molecular descriptor can be embedded into multiple

## Solvent Hazards
There are numerous sources of information
available that provide researchers with details regarding the safety
and hazards inherent to a specific solvent/substance that is being
used. Perhaps most valuable is the MSDS
(Material Safety Data Sheet, sometimes referred to as an SDS that
contains the same information) that is supplied with all materials
and can be easily accessed from a vendor’s Web site. The MSDS is defined as a document that provides
workers with procedures for safely handling or working with a particular
substance (Figure 
). Many companies will also retain an internal repository/database
of these as part of their Health and Safety groups. While variations
occur in the appearance of the MSDS based on the source, these documents
are typically templated and consist of 16 sections with sections 1
and 2 dealing with the identification of the substance (and the supplier)
and a high-level description of the hazards, respectively. Section
3 describes the specification of the ingredients, while measures addressing
First Aid, Firefighting, and Accidental Release are the topics for
sections 4 through 6. Section 7 talks of the handling and storage
of the material, while section 8 focuses on the exposure controls
and necessary personal protection for working with the substance in
question. Sections 9 and 10 report the physical/chemical properties
and the stability/reactivity characteristics of the material in question,
while sections 11 and 12 provide information on toxicological and
ecological studies. Sections 13 and 14 provide guidance for the disposal
and transportation of the chemical substance, with section 15 addressing
information regarding regulatory listings. Section 16 is provided
to disclose any relevant information that has not been captured elsewhere
in the document. Representative MSDS with the section descriptors. Table

some of the properties of these solvents that we will provide an overview
of in this section. Based on space constraints, this is obviously
not a complete list nor is the following discussion an exhaustive
overview as detailed reports of numerous reports on physical properties,
reactivity, and ecological and toxicological profiles of each solvent
exist in the primary literature. The table includes thermal characteristics such as
boiling point,
flash point, and autoignition temperature. The latter two are often
confused, the flash point of a volatile material is the lowest temperature
at which its vapors will ignite if given an ignition source, while
the autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature at which a
substance will spontaneously ignite in a normal atmosphere without
a source of ignition. The NFPA rating system (NFPA 704) provides a
simple visual representation mainly intended for emergency personnel
dealing with a fire or spill to indicate the health (blue), flammability
(red), reactivity (yellow) and special (white) hazards associated
with a specific material. Different colored
sectors are employed to represent the distinct hazards with a number
rating system of 0–4 (0 representing the least and 4 representing
the greatest risk) utilized to rate each of these on the diamond displayed
on the container of the substance. Figure 
 provides an overview of the criteria applied
to assign ratings to materials for each hazard. NFPA rating system. Other labeling systems (HMIS, OSHA HazCom) are
also often used
though they are not discussed here. The
explosive limits for a solvent specify the concentration range of
a material in air which will burn or explode in the presence of an
ignition source and are usually expressed as the percent volume of
the material in the air. The Lower Explosive
Limit (LEL) is the lowest concentration of vapor that will burn in
air and for most flammable gases, it is less than 5% by volume, while
the Upper (or higher) Explosive Limit (UEL) is the highest concentration
of a vapor above which a flame will not spread in the presence of
an ignition source. It is important to note that percentages higher
than the UEL are considered to be “too rich to burn”. The LC50 and LD50 data tabulated provide
a relative assessment to the toxicity of a specific solvent and should
be considered in context. Specifically,
toxicity is divided into multiple categories based on the duration
of exposure. Acute toxicity is typically
associated with a single exposure over a relatively short time, while
chronic toxicity addresses repeated or long-term exposure that occurs
over months to years. LD50 is used to describe acute toxicity and is the median lethal oral
(or dermal) dose predicted to cause death in 50% of the test animals. The values are expressed in milligrams of compound
per kilogram of body weight of the test species (mg/kg). While LD50 is the lethal dose, LC50 refers to the lethal
concentration and is utilized for inhalation-based studies (the values
for the latter can be reported in mg/L, mg/m3, or ppm). Comparisons are often challenging, as it is
important to remember that estimates of the LD50 are specific
to the test animals used in the study and variability is observed
not only between species but also between different studies. As a guideline, compounds with an oral LD50 of 0–50 mg/kg are considered highly toxic, while
an LD50 of >2000 mg/kg is associated with a material
of
low toxicity. Various assessments such as the Hodge/Sterner or Gosselin/Smith/Hodge
scales can be used to compare and provide a more granular description
of LD50 values, and extensive
